elements.content: The reaction of meso-tetraphenylporphyrinatomanganese(II) (MnTPP) and N,7,7-tricyanoquinomethanimine (TCQMI) forms {[MnIIITPP]+}2[TCQMI]2 2−, which possesses a one-dimensional chain with μ1,3-NCN linkages. The reduced [TCQMI]•− dimerizes as [TCQMI]2 2− with a long, central 1.611(8) Å C−C bond and leads to a honeycomb, two-dimensionally layered structure with 24-membered rings. The μ1,3-NCN linkage stabilizes a canted antiferromagnetic (weak ferromagnetic) behavior with T c of 3.7 K.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of meso-tetraphenylporphyrinatomanganese(II) (MnTPP) and N,7,7-tricyanoquinomethanimine (TCQMI) forms {[MnIIITPP]+}2[TCQMI]2 2-, which possesses a one-dimensional chain with μ1,3-NCN linkages. The reduced [TCQMI]⋅- dimerizes as [TCQMI]2 2- with a long, central 1.611(8) Å C-C bond and leads to a honeycomb, two-dimensionally layered structure with 24-membered rings. The μ1,3-NCN linkage stabilizes a canted antiferromagnetic (weak ferromagnetic) behavior with T c of 3.7 K.

elements.content: The reaction of meso-tetraphenylporphyrinatomanganese(II) and N,7,7-tricyanoquinomethanimine leads to a honeycomb, two-dimensionally layered structure with 24-membered rings with a μ1,3-NCN linkage. The linkage stabilizes a canted antiferromagnetic (weak ferromagnetic) behavior with T c of 3.7 K.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of meso-tetraphenylporphyrinatomanganese(II) and N,7,7-tricyanoquinomethanimine leads to a honeycomb, two-dimensionally layered structure with 24-membered rings with a μ1,3-NCN linkage. The linkage stabilizes a canted antiferromagnetic (weak ferromagnetic) behavior with T c of 3.7 K.

elements.content: Tetraphenylporphyrinatomanganese(III) compounds possessing radical anions that bridge the S = 2 MnIII sites comprise a family of unusual linear-chain-structured organic-based ferrimagnets. They are ferrimagnets with magnetic ordering temperatures (T c) up to 28 K and have complex history- and temperature-dependent magnetizations that include extraordinarily high coercivities (∼27 kOe) at low temperature that exceed commercial magnets.
elements.clean_text: Tetraphenylporphyrinatomanganese(III) compounds possessing radical anions that bridge the S = 2 MnIII sites comprise a family of unusual linear-chain-structured organic-based ferrimagnets. They are ferrimagnets with magnetic ordering temperatures (T c) up to 28 K and have complex history- and temperature-dependent magnetizations that include extraordinarily high coercivities (~27 kOe) at low temperature that exceed commercial magnets.

elements.content: The most studied radical anion is [TCNE]•− (TCNE = tetracyanoethylene), although substituted 7,7,8,8-tetracyano-p-quinodimethanes (TCNQ), and chloranil, etc., also stabilize magnetic ordering. To extend this family of materials, we have investigated the reaction of meso-tetraphenylporphyrinatomanganese(II) (MnTPP) and N,7,7-tricyanoquinomethanimine (TCQMI).
elements.clean_text: The most studied radical anion is [TCNE]⋅- (TCNE = tetracyanoethylene), although substituted 7,7,8,8-tetracyano-p-quinodimethanes (TCNQ), and chloranil, etc., also stabilize magnetic ordering. To extend this family of materials, we have investigated the reaction of meso-tetraphenylporphyrinatomanganese(II) (MnTPP) and N,7,7-tricyanoquinomethanimine (TCQMI).

elements.content: This reaction forms nonsolvated [MnIIITPP][TCQMI]. TCQMI was reduced, as evidenced by the νCN IR (KBr) absorptions being reduced from 2230 and 2169 cm−1 for TCQMI0 to 2188 and 2106 cm−1. The structure was determined from single-crystal X-ray diffraction and consists of a warped MnTPP with an average Mn−N distance of 2.023 Å and a σ-[TCQMI]2 2− dimer. [TCQMI]2 2− dimerizes with a (NC)2C−C(CN)2 linkage with a long, central 1.611(8) Å C−C bond (Figure ). The MnIII ion lies out of the plane of the four N atoms bound to it. This bond length is in accordance with the bond lengths exhibited by the related σ dimers of [TCNQ]•− (∼1.6 Å) and [TCNE]•− [1.59(2) Å].
elements.clean_text: This reaction forms nonsolvated [MnIIITPP][TCQMI]. TCQMI was reduced, as evidenced by the νCN IR (KBr) absorptions being reduced from 2230 and 2169 cm-1 for TCQMI0 to 2188 and 2106 cm-1. The structure was determined from single-crystal X-ray diffraction and consists of a warped MnTPP with an average Mn-N distance of 2.023 Å and a σ-[TCQMI]2 2- dimer. [TCQMI]2 2- dimerizes with a (NC)2C-C(CN)2 linkage with a long, central 1.611(8) Å C-C bond (Figure ). The MnIII ion lies out of the plane of the four N atoms bound to it. This bond length is in accordance with the bond lengths exhibited by the related σ dimers of [TCNQ]⋅- (~1.6 Å) and [TCNE]⋅- [1.59(2) Å].

elements.content: On the opposite side of the dimer, the linear NCN fragment bonds to two MnIII ions in a μ1,3-bridging manner with 2.382(2) and 2.241(3) Å separations. The NC bond lengths of the NCN fragment [1.318(4) and 1.161(4) Å] indicate a cyanimine (NCN) structure and not a carbodiimide (NCN) resonance structure. This is consistent with similar structures seen for a series of MnIIISalen compounds bridged by hydrogencyanamide (HNCN) that exhibit the cyanamide form with two different C−N bonds [1.294(4) and 1.171(4) Å]. In contrast, MnIINCN possesses the carbodiimide (NCN) resonance structure with two equivalent C−N bonds (1.23 Å).
elements.clean_text: On the opposite side of the dimer, the linear NCN fragment bonds to two MnIII ions in a μ1,3-bridging manner with 2.382(2) and 2.241(3) Å separations. The NC bond lengths of the NCN fragment [1.318(4) and 1.161(4) Å] indicate a cyanimine (NCN) structure and not a carbodiimide (NCN) resonance structure. This is consistent with similar structures seen for a series of MnIIISalen compounds bridged by hydrogencyanamide (HNCN) that exhibit the cyanamide form with two different C-N bonds [1.294(4) and 1.171(4) Å]. In contrast, MnIINCN possesses the carbodiimide (NCN) resonance structure with two equivalent C-N bonds (1.23 Å).

elements.content: The warped porphyrin rings adopt a staggered orientation, with alternating planes canted. Warping of the porphyrins, particularly of TPP, has been ascribed to the porphyrin shifting to allow more favorable overlap between its orbitals and those of the central metal. This is most likely due to the steric constraints of the dimer. Hence, MnIII−NCN−MnIII linkages with 6.204 Å Mn···Mn separations are present, and the S = 2 MnIII sites are not bonded to a radical. Thus, [MnIIITPP][TCQMI] is best formulated as {[MnIIITPP]+}2[TCQMI]2 2−. The Mn−NCN−Mn linkages lead to one-dimensional chains that are cross-linked by the σ-[TCQMI]2 2− dimer. This leads to a honeycomb two-dimensionally layered structure with 24-membered rings (Figure b). This motif is similar to that reported for tetrakis(2,4,6-triphenylmethyl)porphinatomanganese(III) ([TCNQ]•−; 1), which possesses [TCNQ]2 2−; however, the porphyrin ring is planar. The porphyrin plane warping observed for [MnIIITPP]2[TCQMI]2 is attributed to greater steric interactions for the shorter Mn−NCN−Mn (vs Mn−NCCCN−Mn).
elements.clean_text: The warped porphyrin rings adopt a staggered orientation, with alternating planes canted. Warping of the porphyrins, particularly of TPP, has been ascribed to the porphyrin shifting to allow more favorable overlap between its orbitals and those of the central metal. This is most likely due to the steric constraints of the dimer. Hence, MnIII-NCN-MnIII linkages with 6.204 Å Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn separations are present, and the S = 2 MnIII sites are not bonded to a radical. Thus, [MnIIITPP][TCQMI] is best formulated as {[MnIIITPP]+}2[TCQMI]2 2-. The Mn-NCN-Mn linkages lead to one-dimensional chains that are cross-linked by the σ-[TCQMI]2 2- dimer. This leads to a honeycomb two-dimensionally layered structure with 24-membered rings (Figure b). This motif is similar to that reported for tetrakis(2,4,6-triphenylmethyl)porphinatomanganese(III) ([TCNQ]⋅-; 1), which possesses [TCNQ]2 2-; however, the porphyrin ring is planar. The porphyrin plane warping observed for [MnIIITPP]2[TCQMI]2 is attributed to greater steric interactions for the shorter Mn-NCN-Mn (vs Mn-NCCCN-Mn).

elements.content: Structure of [MnIIITPP]2[TCQMI]2 possessing [TCQMI]2 2− (a) and the 24-membered ring connecting the chains (b). Color code: Mn, red; N, light blue; C, black.
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of [MnIIITPP]2[TCQMI]2 possessing [TCQMI]2 2- (a) and the 24-membered ring connecting the chains (b). Color code: Mn, red; N, light blue; C, black.

elements.content: χT(T) of [MnIIITPP]2[TCQMI]2 is 3.13 emu·K/mol at 300 K, in accordance with the spin-only expectation of 3.00 emu·K/mol for S = 2 MnIII and diamagnetic [TCQMI]2 2−. This is comparable to that reported for 1. Unlike 1, however, upon cooling, χT(T) decreases, and fitting χT(T) above 20 K to the Curie−Weiss expression, χ ∝ (T − θ)−1, gives θ = −19.2 K, indicative of significant antiferromagnetic coupling (Figure ). This deviates from the [MnIIITPP]2[TCNE]2 family of ferrimagnets because they have effective θ values that are significantly positive. Above 15 K, the χT(T) data were fit to a one-dimensional chain model, eq , developed by Fisher and later modified by Smith and Friedberg, with g = 2.08 and J/k B = −2.00 K (−1.39 cm−1 and −4.00 cal/mol).
elements.clean_text: χT(T) of [MnIIITPP]2[TCQMI]2 is 3.13 emu⋅K/mol at 300 K, in accordance with the spin-only expectation of 3.00 emu⋅K/mol for S = 2 MnIII and diamagnetic [TCQMI]2 2-. This is comparable to that reported for 1. Unlike 1, however, upon cooling, χT(T) decreases, and fitting χT(T) above 20 K to the Curie-Weiss expression, χ ∝ (T - θ)-1, gives θ = -19.2 K, indicative of significant antiferromagnetic coupling (Figure ). This deviates from the [MnIIITPP]2[TCNE]2 family of ferrimagnets because they have effective θ values that are significantly positive. Above 15 K, the χT(T) data were fit to a one-dimensional chain model, eq , developed by Fisher and later modified by Smith and Friedberg, with g = 2.08 and J/k B = -2.00 K (-1.39 cm-1 and -4.00 cal/mol).

elements.content: χT(T) continues to decrease with a decrease in the temperature until ∼8 K, where it begins to rise to a maximum of 1.19 emu·K/mol at 4 K before decreasing again. The low magnetization is thought to arise from the spin canting of the MnIII spin sites.
elements.clean_text: χT(T) continues to decrease with a decrease in the temperature until ~8 K, where it begins to rise to a maximum of 1.19 emu⋅K/mol at 4 K before decreasing again. The low magnetization is thought to arise from the spin canting of the MnIII spin sites.

elements.content: Evidence of magnetic ordering can be seen from the in-phase, χ′(T), and out-of-phase, χ′′(T), components of the alternating-current (ac) susceptibility (Figure ). The peak of the 33 Hz component occurs at 3.65 K, while the rise in χ′′(T) upon cooling at 3.76 K provides another value of T c, which averages 3.7 K.
elements.clean_text: Evidence of magnetic ordering can be seen from the in-phase, χ'(T), and out-of-phase, χ''(T), components of the alternating-current (ac) susceptibility (Figure ). The peak of the 33 Hz component occurs at 3.65 K, while the rise in χ''(T) upon cooling at 3.76 K provides another value of T c, which averages 3.7 K.

elements.content: χT(T) (●), χ−1(T) (○), and fit (+) of [MnIIITPP]2[TCQMI]2 to eq .
elements.clean_text: 2  χT(T) (●), χ-1(T) (○), and fit (+) of [MnIIITPP]2[TCQMI]2 to eq .

elements.content:
Both χ′(T) and χ′′(T) are frequency-dependent below 4 K, indicating either a spin glass or superparamagnetic state.

This ordering temperature is in close agreement with the bifurcation temperature (T b) observed below ∼3.2 K observed from the zero-field- and field-cooled magnetization data (not illustrated). The origin of the canted antiferromagnetic/weak ferromagnetic ordering is attributed to the close proximity of the MnIII sites. Similar behavior is seen in MnIIISalen sites bridged by HNCN in a μ1,3 mode with ordering temperatures observed below 2.5 K. However, in contrast to these HNCN-bridged MnIII compounds, no hysteresis loop is evident for [MnIIITPP]2[TCQMI]2 and saturation magnetization is not achieved at 9 T.
elements.clean_text:
Both χ'(T) and χ''(T) are frequency-dependent below 4 K, indicating either a spin glass or superparamagnetic state. 

This ordering temperature is in close agreement with the bifurcation temperature (T b) observed below ~3.2 K observed from the zero-field- and field-cooled magnetization data (not illustrated). The origin of the canted antiferromagnetic/weak ferromagnetic ordering is attributed to the close proximity of the MnIII sites. Similar behavior is seen in MnIIISalen sites bridged by HNCN in a μ1,3 mode with ordering temperatures observed below 2.5 K. However, in contrast to these HNCN-bridged MnIII compounds, no hysteresis loop is evident for [MnIIITPP]2[TCQMI]2 and saturation magnetization is not achieved at 9 T.

elements.content: Thus, the three-atom conjugated bridging NCN provides a pathway to stabilize magnetic ordering, as a canted antiferromagnet (weak ferromagnetic), which has not been observed for the conjugated five-atom NCCCN bridging group.
elements.clean_text: Thus, the three-atom conjugated bridging NCN provides a pathway to stabilize magnetic ordering, as a canted antiferromagnet (weak ferromagnetic), which has not been observed for the conjugated five-atom NCCCN bridging group.

elements.content: In-phase, χ′(T), and out-of-phase, χ′′(T), susceptibility at 33 (●), 100 (◼), and 1000 (▲) Hz.

metadata.title: Stabilization of Magnetic Ordering Observed for the Bridging NCN Group
